origin: One of three original counties created in the Plymouth Colony
etymology: After its county seat of Barnstable, which is named after the English town of Barnstaple

origin: From part of Hampshire County. Government abolished in 2000.
etymology: For the English county of Berkshire

origin: One of three original counties created in the Plymouth Colony
etymology: For its original county seat of Bristol, Massachusetts, which is named for the English port city of Bristol kept

origin: From Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Islands, which had been part of Dukes County, New York until Massachusetts gained it in 1691
etymology: Formerly a part of Dukes County, New York until 1691, the land at one time was the possession of the Duke of York

origin: One of four original counties created in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Government abolished in 1999.
etymology: For the English county of Essex

origin: From part of Hampshire County. Government abolished in 1997.
etymology: For Benjamin Franklin, early American scientist, diplomat, and politician

origin: From part of Hampshire County. Government abolished in 1998.
etymology: John Hampden, the famous 17th century English parliamentarian

origin: From unorganized territory in the western part of the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Government abolished 1999.
etymology: For the English county of Hampshire

origin: One of four original counties created in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Government abolished in 1997.
etymology: For the English county of Middlesex

origin: From Nantucket Island which had been part of Dukes County, New York until Massachusetts gained it in 1691.
etymology: The Town of Nantucket, itself derived from a Wampanoag word meaning "place of peace"
For the English county of Norfolk

origin: One of three original counties created in the Plymouth Colony.
etymology: For its seat of Plymouth, which is named for the English port city of Plymouth

origin: One of four original counties created in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Government abolished in 1999.
etymology: For the English county of Suffolk

origin: From parts of Hampshire County, Middlesex County and Suffolk County. Government abolished in 1998.
etymology: For its county seat of Worcester, which is named in honor of the English city of Worcester and the English Civil War Battle of Worcester in 1651, a Parliamentarian victory
